Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Materials Design and Wavefunction Engineering in Lead Sulfide Based Nanocrystals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Paul G. Van Patten of Middle Tennessee State University is supported by this award from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program in the Division of Chemistry to study the reactions between lead sulfide (PbS) quantum dots (QDs) and a variety of salts containing main group metals, first-row transition metals, or lanthanide cations. These reactions will result in partial or complete cation exchange within the QDs to produce a variety of novel, metal sulfide QDs that have not been prepared or studied before. Varying the distribution of metal cations within the QDs will permit tuning of electronic energy levels and carrier wavefunctions, thus imparting novel reactivity and/or optical properties to these materials. The project will include structural, optical, and even magnetic characterization of these new materials with an eye toward understanding structure/property relationships and toward identifying materials with strong potential for technological application.

The exploration of new materials is essential to the development of future technologies and has always been a central goal of the chemical sciences. This project will investigate several new materials derived from PbS quantum dots, which have themselves garnered significant attention for their solar energy conversion potential. The new materials developed here are expected to cover a wide spectrum of chemical and optical properties to further improve on the already-promising characteristics of PbS QDs. This research project will also provide valuable education and research experience for several junior scientists, including master's students, undergraduates, and even high school summer interns from the American Chemical Society's Project SEED program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is widely believed by chemists, physicists, and materials scientists that new nanomaterials will continue to play an important role in the technologies that emerge 21st Century. Colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals, also known as "quantum dots," are a class of nanomaterials that seem to show particular promise for electronic, solar energy, and light-emitting technologies. This project, led by Dr. P. G. Van Patten of the Chemistry Department at Middle Tennessee State University, has studied cation exchange reactions, which are of interest for the production of new types of quantum dots that are not accessible by other known reaction pathways. Although cation exchange reactions have shown promise for quantum dot synthesis, there have been limitations, and Van Patten's work has been aimed at making these reactions more useful and general.

This work has yielded two key technical merit outcomes/impacts that promise to improve the utility and generality of cation exchange reactions for quantum dot synthesis. The first key outcome is the first demonstration of a way to scale up these reactions to make them synthetically practical for preparing large amounts of product material. A few breakthroughs were necessary to enable this outcome. We have designed a new reagent mixture containing silver cations in combination with other molecules (called ligands) that render the silver cations soluble in the mixture and also make them reactive toward cation exchange at room temperature. The silver cations serve as an intermediate as they are highly mobile inside the quantum dots. This means they can easily move in to replace another cation, and they can also easily move out to be replaced by other cations. In this way, the silver cations can enable fast, multi-step cation exchange reactions to occur at room temperature that would not be possible in a single-step process. We have prepared similar types of cation exchange reagents with other types of cations, too, showing that it may be a general approach to rapid cation exchange reactions. The second key outcome of this work is to refute the idea that high quality materials cannot be prepared by fast, room-temperature cation exchange reactions. Early failures to produce high-quality light-emitting quantum dots by this method led researchers to conclude that the room temperature process simply did not allow adequate relaxation of the ions within the crystal lattice to produce the near-perfect crystal that is desired for good optical properties. We have shown conclusively that highly emissive materials can be prepared via cation exchange if the quantum dot surfaces are adequtely protected from degradation during the reaction. Together, these two outcomes enable a general, rapid, and scalable approach to high quality quantum dots via cation exchange transformations. It is yet to be determined what types of new materials will become accessible through these reactions.

The broader impact outcomes from this project were equally positive. The project yielded opportunities for outreach to lay persons and school children and also served as a training ground for sixteen junior researchers, including 7 high school students, 6 MTSU undergraduate students, 1 student who was both an undergraduate and masters student during the project, 1 other M.S. student, and 1 part-time postdoctoral researcher. These students produced 2 published Chemistry M.S. theses, 2 peer-reviewed publications (with another in preparation at the time of this writing), and 9 conference presentations, including 1 invited talk at an American Chemical Society National Meeting. The professional outcomes for these junior scientists have all been positive. Three are still working/seeking degrees at MTSU, whereas all the others have been placed in higher degree programs or good chemistry-related jobs. Aside from the career outcomes for the project participants, the project fostered multiple outreach opportunities in Middle Tennessee in which project participants, including the PI, gave presentations, demonstrations, or led hands-on activities related to nanoscience for audiences of lay people. Although there were adults in attendance, the primary audience for these activities were school children ranging from elementary through high school. About 250 total individuals attended these outreach events.
